results.content:
Sadly, Im quite dissapointed about this course and I want to share my thoughts.

I picked it because I was looking for a introduction to TDD approach when building React applications. I was a total beginner back then and as I kept reading both description and comments, I thought it would be great for me to start from basics.

First part of the course satisfied me. The instructor started with some theory an basic concepts and jumped into real life code examples, that really helped me grasp the TDD. Thank you for that, 5/5 by now.

But then everything went downhill.
Instructor introduced second mini-project (which is 2/3 of the course) with a lot of specific libraries, extra packages and third party libraries), which narrowed the accesibility of the course only to people, who actually wants to test their apps using these niche libraries. Without knowledge or 'need' to learn these libraries, the rest of the course (2/3 !) was completely useless to me.

If instructor focused more on 'base' concept of testing, explained it thoroughly, THEN added as bonus testing redux and stuff, it would be fine; but instead I got a course that to understand and use most parts of it, requires me to have extra unnecessary knowledge about 3-party libs.

I wouldnt suggest this course to learn TDD in a way this course is designed now, because only 1/3 of this course is usefull stuff (first project) and the rest is testing redux and mentioned niche libraries, that in my opinion arent neccessary to learn TDD. And even if I myself dont need to use the other parts of testing process, still, I believe 90 mins of course isnt enought to cover TDD.

results.content:
It was more basic then I thought it would be.  I think it covered the 'how' reasonably well, but I was disappointed at how little was mentioned about the design of the code and what you should be thinking about while writing tests, and distinctions like "clean" tests vs. "dirty" tests.  

Further, there were a number of times throughout the course where a bug comes up that isn't covered by the tests, and those would have been an excellent opportunity to let people know that as they see and notice those cases, they should add tests to cover them. Instead, it seems like the code was just fixed directly without adding tests and we moved on.

This is a useful introduction to TDD in the context of React + Redux, but it doesn't go much beyond a junior level.

results.content:
The course is presented professionally.

It's a good introduction to tdd and bdd in the React ecosystem using Jest and Enzyme. But don't let the title fool you -> 'MASTERING Test and Behavior Driven Development' this is NOT.

You will get a basic overview of some testing of React Components, Redux Action Creators (including async actions) and Reducers. But there is a LOT missing. There is no discussion of how you should structure your directories in large projects -- is placing *.test.js files next to the *.js file a best practice? I don't know from this course. There is no discussion of what kinds of things we should be testing for - I don't for a second believe that the tests written in this course provide comprehensive coverage for a production application. What happens when my fetch method fails? Do we test an error handler? How?

Don't get me wrong; I'm not completely trying to tear down this course. I think it's a good introduction but I think calling it 'Mastering Test and Behavior Driven Development' is quite a bit misleading.

You will come away with some basic knowledge of Jest and Enzyme - probably comfortable enough to start doing your own research in the documentation.

I did learn from this course but it took a LOT of repeat listenings to understand complicated sections and even then I'm still a little bit hazy on parts. The building of an application that queries an API was a good exercise but could have been explained so much better. 

The whole course seems rushed and very complicated sections seemed to be passed by far too quickly. For example the Async testing with Thunk is so poorly explained and rushed through that when you get to the end you are told to read through the documentation for a fuller explanation. I also feel as if the explanations of the modules used through out this course are simply read from their own webpages. There is no broken down or simplified explanation. 

I would recommend this course if you already have a fair to medium graps on React and Redux with and are familiar with the ES6 syntax.

results.content:
I loved the course. It was relatively short, but not because it lacks content. I'm quite experienced with react & redux and this really opened my eyes to what I can test, and in which ways. Want to test components, action creators, reducers or even async actions? This has it all. 
All I could ask for is adding new more advanced topics/use cases every now and then :)

Well worth the 15 bucks or so 
--- IF ---
you are already familiar with at least some react. You will learn how to develop your application using TDD/BDD, or how to test your existing application to a good extent, but you will not "learn" React and/or Redux per se from this course.

results.content:
Often I hear developers using React without writing tests and that it's difficult to write tests for front end development. 

It turns out, that's not true and there are great tools for writing tests for React. I really value test driven development and learning through this course was much better for me, with the tests and code happening in parallel, than other courses.

It could do a little bit more work on what's happening conceptually in React, but I'm pretty theory heavy, so overall I think it's a great course to get started with React.

results.content:
The course worths the investment

David show us real world examples of how to write tests and which kind of tests you need to do to ensure your application is robust and bug-free

However, you need to be familiar with TDD before in order to understand why things are done the way they are and to leverage important concepts

I missed a few more scenarios where we can explore test scenarios for external API call's, maybe it can be done into a separate course: Mastering API testing using React (my suggestion)

results.content:
This is my 5th Udemy course now and probably the most frustrating one I've taken.

David clearly knows his stuff. He's very up to date with all the latest practices so you can count on him that whatever you're learning is very current.

However, sometimes the smartest people don't make the best teachers.  What David needs to improve on is his delivery and teaching style. 

- Delivery: Talk slower, and ELI5 more. Certain things you can talk less about, like what constructor and lifecycle functions are. But take the time to explain the how and why for complex topics (like mock store, fetch mock).

- Teaching style: I usually categorise teaching styles into 'Show-ers' and 'Teachers'. Right now I'd say you are a 'Show-er' which is great if you are an advanced student and want to great through a course asap. But for us noobies we need a teacher to guide us more into the know how of certain things. 

I think if you are able to improve on your teaching style, you will easily become the best React/Node instructors there is.

This is a very solid course. It walks you through writing tests for rendering, state existence, state addition/removal, reducer test and a few more. It also exposes you to a modern approach that is mostly up-to-date.

The only suggestions I have to the author are:
* Don't be afraid to press Enter. Break that line if it doesn't fit (or use prettier in vscode);
* Explain more thoroughly the concepts behind packages that you install (e.g. mockStore);
* Keep it even more up to date. There was no mention of `Enzyme.configure({ adapter })` in your video other than that short disclaimer.
* There's no propTypes testing...

results.content:
David's course is instructive and I certainly feel like I've come away knowing how to do react and redux testing with jest and enzyme.

It's clear the course was written a little before react 16.0 and the update for this to include enzyme adapters didn't quite work for me but I did get it working without too much effort. However I do think the change was big enough to warrant an updated video or two for that section instead of a of PDF instruction sheet.

It was also apparent that the material was totally dependent on the set up of create-react-app and I would have appreciated a section on setting up / adding jest and enzyme for an existing project not based on create-react-app.

Otherwise I would have rated this course 4+

Straight to they point, and with a relatively fast-pace. I think this course is more oriented towards people who really know what they are looking for (just coding tests) since there were no really in-depth lessons about good/standard testing practices or processes, nor methods for testing compund components/custom hooks, and so on. 

It is not a bad course since overall I learned many things, but in my opinion, it needs and update and come extra content.

Be ready for coming up with console errors and do some research online.
